head.hi: The policy of the War Department in not exchanging prisoners.

body.p: We print in another column a communication on the exchange of prisoners of war, which has been sent us by Walt Whitman, who, we understand, is a steadfast member of a republican family, & therefore not likely to find fault with the administration without grounds. Our government seems to be desirous of building itself a name for bad faith toward its captured soldiers, that will be a stain on it forever & in both immediate & prospective results will certainly lose it more than it will gain.

It is now well known by all in the inside circles that the stick about exchanging the blacks is only a pretense for popular effect, & that the course policy of the War Department is to let the Union prisoners south die off while we return the captured southerners.

Mr Whitman we think utters the general opinion of all the candid men of his own & every party in the land, in saying in plain terms that the wholesale deaths of our sons & brethren in southern stockades the past year rest on no other than the heads of members of our own government.
